  • 施泰德被判缓刑并罚款 110 万欧元
  • 首位前大众董事会成员因柴油丑闻欺诈被判刑
  • 前高管、工程师也被判刑和罚款

前奥迪老板鲁珀特·施塔德勒因在2015年柴油丑闻中的疏忽欺诈罪于周二被慕尼黑法院判处一年零九个月缓刑，成为第一位被判此刑的前大众汽车董事会成员。

法院称，这位前老板被罚款 110 万欧元（120 万美元），这笔罚款将上缴国库和非政府组织。

法官表示，如果这位前首席执行官承认指控，他将面临 1.5 至 2 年的刑期。

他的律师乌尔里克·托勒-格罗尔 (Ulrike Thole-Groll) 今年 5 月表示，施泰德并不知道车辆被操纵以及买家受到伤害，但他承认这是一种可能性，并承认需要给予更多照顾。

检察官最初希望对施泰德处以 200 万欧元的罚款，理由是施泰德在奥迪和大众的工资以及他的金融和房地产资产。

施泰德的审判是柴油丑闻后最引人注目的法庭诉讼程序之一，自 2020 年以来一直在进行。

奥迪母公司大众集团(VOWG_p.DE)和奥迪于 2015 年承认使用非法软件在排放测试中作弊。

据检察官称，工程师在测试台上操纵发动机的方式符合法定废气排放值，但在道路上却不符合。丑闻曝光后，施泰德被指控未能阻止被盗汽车的销售。

他此前曾否认这些指控。

同样与施塔德勒一起受审的前奥迪高管沃尔夫冈·哈茨被判处两年缓刑和 40 万欧元罚款，而第三名被告工程师乔瓦尼·P. 则被判处一年零九个月和 5 万欧元罚款。

检察官办公室和被告可以在7月4日之前提出上诉。

（1 美元 = 0.9141 欧元）

Joern Poltz、Victoria Waldersee 报道；弗里德里克·海涅 (Friederike Heine) 和杰森·尼利 (Jason Neely) 编辑; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 12:00:44 GMT https://www.reuters.com/business/autos-transportation/audi-ex-boss-handed-suspended-sentence-1-year-nine-months-diesel-trial-2023-06-27/ https://www.reuters.com/business/autos-transportation/audi-ex-boss-handed-suspended-sentence-1-year-nine-months-diesel-trial-2023-06-27/Jörn Poltz大众汽车DIESELGATE/试用（更新 2，PIX） Encrypted phone service 'Encrochat' shutdown leads to 6,500 arrests - Europol

欧洲警务机构欧洲刑警组织周二表示，捣毁了一家为犯罪分子提供据称安全加密通信的地下公司 Encrochat，导致 6,500 多人被捕，并被没收了 9 亿欧元（合 9.8 亿美元）资产。

该系统在 2020 年 6 月突然关闭时估计有 60,000 名用户，欧洲刑警组织在次月透露，执法官员几个月来一直在拦截用户的通信。

欧洲刑警组织在周二的一份声明中首次概述了此次取缔行动的结果，称此次行动“给欧洲及其他地区的有组织犯罪集团带来了冲击”。

欧洲刑警组织表示，警方已分析了超过 1.15 亿条“犯罪对话”，有助于防止“暴力袭击、谋杀未遂、腐败和大规模毒品运输”。

该机构表示，此次行动所引发的调查迄今已查获 100 吨可卡因、3000 万粒“化学毒品”药丸、近千辆汽车、数百处房产以及数十艘船只和飞机。

警方声明没有详细说明 Encrochat 的所有者本人是否已被捕。

法国和荷兰当局定于周二晚些时候在里尔举行新闻发布会。

法国、荷兰和英国警方此前已于 2020 年公布了与 Encrochat 相关的调查的部分结果，德国警方则于 2021 年公布了部分结果。

Encrochat 以每台约 1,000 欧元的价格出售改装的 Android 移动设备，并向用户收取高额订阅费，并承诺他们的通信将保持加密和保密。

2020 年 6 月，其身份不明的运营商显然意识到自己受到了威胁，该网站突然关闭。

欧洲刑警组织表示，该公司已通过法国的服务器传输加密通信。

欧洲刑警组织周二表示：“最终，有可能放置一种技术设备来超越加密技术并获取用户的信件。”

（1 美元 = 0.9169 欧元）

托比·斯特林报道；克里斯蒂娜·芬奇编辑; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 11:58:09 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/encrypted-phone-service-encrochat-shutdown-leads-6500-arrests-europol-2023-06-27/ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/encrypted-phone-service-encrochat-shutdown-leads-6500-arrests-europol-2023-06-27/Reuters欧洲刑警组织ENCROCHAT/（PIX） Prince Harry should get just 500 pounds in phone-hacking case, London court told

周二，一家英国小报集团的代表律师告诉伦敦高等法院，哈里王子因一次承认的非法信息收集事件最多应获得 500 英镑（637 美元）的赔偿。

查尔斯国王的小儿子哈里是 100 多人起诉《每日镜报》、《星期日镜报》和《星期日人物》的出版商镜报集团报业 (MGN) 的 100 多人之一，指控其窃听电话和非法收集信息。

他们的律师声称，1991 年至 2011 年间，所有三份 MGN 报纸的非法活动“普遍存在”。

本月早些时候，这位王位第五顺位继承人在证人席上度过了一天半的时间，接受盘问，指控他从 1996 年（当时他还是个孩子）以来的 15 年间一直是 MGN 游戏的非法目标。

当他成为130 多年来第一位出现在证人席上的英国高级王室成员时，他的盘问始于 MGN 的律师安德鲁·格林 (Andrew Green) 就一次非法信息收集事件的道歉。

MGN 在 5 月份的审判开始时承认，2004 年，一名私家侦探曾在伦敦一家夜总会非法收集有关哈利的证据，并为此“毫无保留地道歉”。

然而，该出版商在周二发布的法庭文件中辩称，除了承认的一件事之外，哈利“未能发现任何针对他的语音邮件拦截的证据，也没有发现任何其他非法收集其私人信息的证据” 。

格林说：“苏塞克斯公爵应该获得最多 500 英镑的奖励，因为单张发票上提到他的名字涉及个别场合的询问，而发票上的小金额 - 75 英镑 - 表明询问是有限的。”

萨姆·托宾报道；莎拉·杨编辑; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 11:49:08 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/prince-harry-should-get-just-500-stg-phone-hacking-case-london-court-told-2023-06-27/ https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/prince-harry-should-get-just-500-stg-phone-hacking-case-london-court-told-2023-06-27/Sam Tobin英国皇室成员/哈里法庭损害赔偿 Sierra Leone's President Bio leads presidential election

塞拉利昂总统朱利叶斯·马达·比奥 (Julius Maada Bio) 在总统选举计票工作中处于领先地位，西非国家选举委员会周一在计票 60% 后表示。

59 岁的比奥正在竞选连任，对手有 12 名。他最大的竞争对手是全国人民代表大会（APC）候选人萨穆拉·卡马拉（Samura Kamara），后者在 2018 年上次选举中以微弱优势输给了比奥。

临时结果表显示，到目前为止，Bio 已获得超过 100 万张选票，而卡马拉的选票不到 80 万张。该委员会周一下午表示，最终核实结果将在未来 48 小时内公布。

选举一直很紧张。 APC 表示，选举当天，他们的选举代表在三个地区遭到袭击和恐吓。选举委员会周日概述了几起官员遭到殴打或恐吓的事件。

现场的一名路透社记者称，周日，警察在选举后的新闻发布会上包围了塞拉利昂反对党总部大楼，随后发现一名妇女受重伤且没有脉搏。

塞拉利昂人担心，结果公布后可能会发生更多骚乱，特别是如果 13 名候选人中没有一人获得 55% 的选票，这种情况将引发前两名候选人之间的决选。

该国仍处于 1991 年至 2002 年内战的泥沼之中，这场内战导致 50,000 多人死亡，数百人受伤。

国际观察员对计票缺乏透明度表示担忧。

选举观察员兼律师 Augustine Sorie-Sengbe Marrah 表示，选举委员会有责任通过透明度来解决任何不公平的指控。

“因为如果你说反对党声称 ECSL（塞拉利昂选举委员会）没有提供公平的竞争环境，我认为他们有必要确保他们的每一步都是透明的，并对所有各方负责。方式，”马拉告诉路透社。

周一晚间临时结果公布后，比奥向全国发表讲话，呼吁公民保持和平。

他在电视讲话中说：“在选举结果公布期间和之后维持和平对我们每个人都有利害关系。”

库珀·伊维恩报道；作者：Anait Miridzhanian；编辑：Estelle Shirbon、Bate Felix 和 Aurora Ellis ; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 11:36:59 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/sierra-leone-provisional-results-incumbent-bio-leading-presidential-race-2023-06-26/ https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/sierra-leone-provisional-results-incumbent-bio-leading-presidential-race-2023-06-26/Reuters利昂选举/（更新 2、电视、PIX） Putin praises Russian troops for putting down mutiny as Prigozhin jet reaches BelarusSummary:
  • 从罗斯托夫追踪到的喷气式飞机似乎降落在明斯克附近
  • 当局撤销对叛变者的刑事诉讼
  • 普京向部队发表讲话
  • 普里戈任否认试图推翻政府

俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京在周二的一次仪式上赞扬了俄罗斯军队和安全部队成员，在瓦格纳集团首席执行官叶夫根尼·普里戈任领导的雇佣军叛变失败后，他试图重申自己的权威。

一架与普里戈任有关的飞机从俄罗斯抵达白俄罗斯，据信载着这名雇佣军头目流亡，三天前，普里戈任突然取消了他的战士向首都发起的叛变。

据俄新社报道，当局撤销了对瓦格纳的刑事诉讼，这显然满足了周六晚间达成的化解危机协议的一个条件。

普京对聚集在克里姆林宫建筑群广场上的大约 2,500 名安全人员表示，人民和武装部队团结一致反对叛军雇佣军。

国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古也加入了他的行列，解雇绍伊古是叛乱分子的主要要求之一。

普京还要求默哀一分钟，以纪念在叛乱中丧生的俄罗斯军事飞行员。战斗机在飞往莫斯科的过程中击落了几架飞机，尽管他们在地面上没有遇到抵抗。

普里戈任是普京的前盟友，曾被判刑，他的雇佣军在乌克兰战争中进行了最血腥的战斗并造成重大人员伤亡。他曾表示，应俄罗斯总统、普京亲密盟友亚历山大·卢卡申科的邀请，他将前往邻国白俄罗斯。

他计划的流亡之旅的细节没有公开，也没有确认他在叛变后三天内的行踪，包括他是否在周二早上飞往白俄罗斯的飞机上。

航班跟踪服务Flightradar24的网站显示，一架巴西航空工业公司莱格赛600喷气式飞机的识别码与美国制裁文件中与普里戈任相关的飞机相匹配，正在下降到白俄罗斯首都明斯克附近的着陆高度。

它首先出现在罗斯托夫上空的追踪站点上，罗斯托夫是俄罗斯南部城市普里戈任的战士在叛变期间捕获的。

他最后一次出现在公众面前是在周六晚上，在命令手下下车后，他坐在一辆SUV的后座上离开罗斯托夫，当时他面带微笑，与旁观者击掌。

普京在周一晚上的电视讲话中表示，叛变领导人背叛了他们的祖国，但他没有提到普里戈任的名字。他说，瓦格纳战士将被允许在白俄罗斯定居、加入俄罗斯军队或回家。

克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫在周二的新闻发布会上表示，结束叛乱的协议正在实施中，但他不知道普里戈任在哪里。他还表示，他不知道有多少瓦格纳战斗机将与国防部签订合同。

他驳斥了普京对权力的掌控因叛乱而动摇的观点，称这种想法是“歇斯底里”。

抗议示威

62 岁的普里戈任表示，他在接到命令将自己的组织置于国防部指挥之下后，发动了叛变，以拯救自己的组织。

他说，他的战士在几乎到达莫斯科后于周六停止了战斗，以避免流血，并对被迫在途中击落飞机感到遗憾。

普里戈任周一在音频信息中说：“我们去示威是为了抗议，而不是为了推翻该国政府。”

普京在隔夜的讲话中，这是他自兵变以来的首次公开评论，他确认俄罗斯飞行员已被杀害，并感谢俄罗斯人表现出的爱国团结。

普京表示，俄罗斯的敌人希望看到该国“陷入血腥内乱”，但俄罗斯不会屈服于“任何勒索、任何制造内部动乱的企图”。

俄罗斯领导人试图表明，叛变流产后局势正在恢复正常。普京周一晚上会见了安全部门负责人，其中包括国防部长绍伊古。

在乌克兰，总统泽伦斯基在夜间讲话中表示，周一，军队在前线的所有地区都取得了进展，并称这是“快乐的一天”。

基辅希望，随着乌克兰继续反攻，夺回被占领土，俄罗斯的叛变企图所造成的混乱将削弱俄罗斯的防御。它周一声称已经占领了南部的第九个村庄，自六月初以来它一直在向那里推进。

乌克兰空军发言人表示，周二俄罗斯空袭后，乌克兰中部城市克列缅丘克传出爆炸声。

克列缅丘克是乌克兰一家炼油厂所在地，自去年俄罗斯入侵乌克兰以来，该炼油厂多次遭到俄罗斯袭击。乌克兰官员表示该系统已不再运行。

路透社记者报道 Angus MacSwan 撰稿 Peter Graff 编辑; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 11:34:04 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/putin-pays-tribute- Russian-pilots-killed-fighting-mutineers-2023-06-27/ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/putin-pays-tribute- Russian-pilots-killed-fighting-mutineers-2023-06-27/Reuters乌克兰危机/俄罗斯（总结 7、电视、PIX、图文） Trump team lobbying for primary rule changes to boost his 2024 chances

前总统唐纳德·特朗普 (Donald Trump) 的团队和几个州的消息人士告诉路透社，前总统唐纳德·特朗普 (Donald Trump) 正在利用他与关键初选州忠诚者的关系来游说投票规则和日期，这可能会巩固他在 2024 年共和党总统提名竞选中的领跑者地位。

特朗普的竞选团队正在与共和党各州政党接触，推动这些变革，共和党官员正在为明年初 2024 年 11 月 5 日总统选举之前开始的竞选设定参数。

一些州在 2020 年采取了对特朗普有利的规则，以阻止对时任总统的竞争，而密歇根州最近的变化似乎增强了他在争取代表确定党提名人的竞争中的优势。特朗普竞选团队的联合竞选经理告诉路透社，现在特朗普竞选团队正在另外六个州倡导进行修改。

“我们与全国各地的缔约国合作参与这一进程，”克里斯·拉奇维塔在接受采访时说。 “总统给我们的挑战是赢得每一天，赢得每一场战斗。这只是其中的一部分。”

尽管众所周知，特朗普团队正试图在 2024 年之前对重要投票州的共和党机制施加影响，但此前并未报道过这一努力的规模。

在某些支持特朗普的州提前投票可能会给这位前总统带来超越共和党竞争对手的动力。政治分析人士表示，举行预选而不是初选也可能会给忠于他的草根活动人士带来更多影响力。

拉奇维塔证实，内华达州是该州竞选的目标之一，内华达州是一个早期初选州，共和党领导层对特朗普友好。他拒绝详细说明竞选团队正在寻求的改变，也拒绝透露他们参与的其他州的名称。

5月，内华达州共和党起诉该州，要求允许举行党团会议，称被迫举行初选侵犯了宪法权利。

拉西维塔表示，特朗普的竞选团队支持这起诉讼。一位与内华达州共和党关系密切的消息人士在诉讼之前告诉路透社，特朗普的竞选团队正在游说召开党团会议。

一位与爱达荷州共和党关系密切的消息人士告诉路透社，特朗普的盟友一直在游说在五月之前举行提名竞赛。爱达荷州共和党人周末决定提前举行党团会议而不是初选，这似乎让特朗普在该州获得了优势。

特朗普的游说努力显示出他在 2016 年随心所欲的竞选活动中所缺乏的成熟程度，并突显出在几个州政党都由效忠者主导的情况下，他将如何受益。

特朗普并不是唯一一个试图塑造对他有利的 2024 年战场的人。民主党全国委员会今年 2 月批准了乔·拜登总统对该党 2024 年初选日程的调整，赋予黑人选民在提名过程中更大的发言权，并为拜登开辟了一条更轻松的道路。

民主党的改革提升了南卡罗来纳州和佐治亚州在其他州中的地位，并降低了著名的爱荷华州预选会议的地位。

密歇根州共和党策略师杰森·罗伊表示，特朗普竞选活动的阴谋具有拉西维塔制定的战略的特征。拉西维塔是弗吉尼亚州的一名长期政治人物，他称拉西维塔为“熟练的大会计票员”。

罗伊说：“任何时候，只要你能在大会或党团会议上选出代表，这对特朗普来说都比参加选票更有利。” “他在活动人士中的支持率明显高于普通民众。”

在 2024 年共和党各州提名之战中，估计有 2,467 名代表可供争夺。竞选通常在所有州都有机会投票之前就已经有效结束，这意味着像内华达州和密歇根州这样相对较早投票的州可能非常重要。

为了特朗普的胜利，密歇根州的共和党人最近同意通过核心小组会议选出三分之二以上的代表，而在这些会议上，活跃的成员往往拥有最大的影响力。这一变化是由于民主党领导人决定将国家资助的初选日期提前到共和党全国委员会 (RNC) 规定允许的日期。

拉奇维塔表示，特朗普竞选团队将自己作为该州和共和党全国委员会的资源，但建议他们或多或少地让这一过程进行下去。

“有时需要轻触而不是重触，”拉奇维塔说。

爱达荷州、内华达州和密歇根州的共和党州没有回应有关特朗普竞选活动的置评请求。

德桑蒂斯观看

几十年来，游说改变主要规则一直是两个主要政党竞选活动的主要内容。

两名竞选消息人士告诉路透社，支持佛罗里达州州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯的团队正在监视特朗普的游说努力，并已确定了三四个州，他们也在倡导改革。

据知情人士透露，他的团队还在与数十个州的政党官员接触，努力与权力掮客建立良好关系，建立代表州长参加初选的代表名单，并研究潜在的规则变化。

这些人士表示，他们特别密切关注的州包括内华达州和爱达荷州，特朗普阵营在这两个州一直很活跃。

支持德桑蒂斯的外部超级政治行动委员会“永不退缩”的一位消息人士表示，他们正在监视阿拉巴马州，该州可能会在赢得代表所需的最低门槛方面发生变化。竞选活动还密切关注密苏里州，共和党人计划在那里举行党团会议，但尚未制定代表选举规则。

“你必须逐个州进行。这不是一个容易的过程。你必须组织起来才能做到这一点，”德桑蒂斯竞选团队的一位消息人士表示。

幕后之争必须在 10 月 1 日之前结束，届时所有州都需要告诉共和党全国委员会他们将如何进行提名程序。

德桑蒂斯竞选团队的一位消息人士和“永不退缩”组织的另一位消息人士对投票率较低、需要选民付出更多努力才能参与的预选会议实际上是否对特朗普更好表示怀疑。

特朗普竞选团队认为他们的支持者充满热情，因此更有可能出席，而德桑蒂斯一方则认为更富有、受过高等教育的共和党人——他们的民意调查结果往往更好——更有可能有时间参加。

Tim Reid 的补充报道 Colleen Jenkins 和 Alistair Bell 编辑; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 10:22:13 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/us/trump-team-lobbying-primary-rule-changes-boost-his-2024-chances-2023-06-27/ https://www.reuters.com/world/us/trump-team-lobbying-primary-rule-changes-boost-his-2024-chances-2023-06-27/Nathan Layne, Alexandra Ulmer, Gram Slattery美国选举/特朗普 (PIX) Jaunts in jets, not risky adventures, the norm for wealthy travelers

亿万富翁理查德·布兰森 (Richard Branson) 身穿蓝色连身裤，悬挂在纽约市上空 1,200 英尺的摩天大楼一侧，上周在 Twitter 上敦促观众尽情享受生活并尝试新事物。

作为太空旅游公司维珍银河的创始人，布兰森是少数推动探索和体验极限的超级富有企业家之一。布兰森和维珍集团没有立即对太空旅游的风险发表评论。

一些亿万富翁像布兰森和亚马逊创始人杰夫·贝索斯那样飞入太空。其他富有的旅行者乘坐潜水器探索远洋客轮泰坦尼克号的残骸。上周参加那次旅行的五人丧生。但据华尔街投资者、银行家、律师和那些希望出售异国度假的人表示，大多数非常富有的人想要一种不那么极端但独特的体验。

巴西旅行社 Latitudes Viagens 首席执行官 Alexandre Cymbalista 表示：“我们的公众已经可以入住豪华酒店，他们想要的是不同的体验和个人发展。”

在他的旅行中，有一名摄影师来纪念这一事件，并有一名医生进行即时急救。

杰弗里·肯特 (Geoffrey Kent) 是拥有 61 年历史的豪华旅游运营商 Abercrombie & Kent 的创始人，他花了一年多的时间规划定制旅行，从博茨瓦纳的狩猎之旅到喜马拉雅山徒步旅行。

每次旅行费用为 25 万至 30 万美元，肯特有时会提出不寻常的要求，包括帮助沙特王子实现驾驶飞机上下航空母舰的梦想。

但肯特表示，某些旅行方式风险太大。

随着股市的繁荣和企业家从家族企业中套现，百万富翁的队伍正在不断壮大。例如，瑞士信贷表示，2019 年至 2021 年间，身家超过 5000 万美元的人数增加了 50% 以上。信息技术服务和咨询公司凯捷估计，全球有 21 万名净资产超过 3000 万美元的人。

随着投资组合的增长，对体验的需求也在增长——从住在非洲野生动物保护区的高端帐篷，到苏富比拍卖师解释手表的趋势，再到在没有人群的情况下欣赏世界著名的艺术品。

特殊通道

例如，高盛(GS.N)为最高净值客户提供了迈阿密巴塞尔艺术博览会的参观活动，该活动由负责家族办公室艺术和收藏品战略的内部艺术专家莫妮卡·赫斯林顿 (Monica Heslington) 组织。消息人士熟悉情况。

高盛的一位发言人表示，去年，作为巴塞尔艺术展的一部分，其客户参加了迈阿密鲁贝尔博物馆举办的一场以不同艺术家为主题的活动。

美国银行(BAC.N)与豪华旅行社 Indagare 建立了合作伙伴关系，为资产超过 5000 万美元的人士提供服务。美国银行没有立即发表评论。

Indagare 首席执行官梅丽莎·比格斯·布拉德利 (Melissa Biggs Bradley) 预计今年将有大约 1,000 名游客。 Indagare 花费约 20,000 美元，提供意大利餐馆老板 Massimo Bottura 拥有的摩德纳一家精品酒店为期三天的住宿，同时还可以参观法拉利总部并有机会试驾汽车。

她说，前往南北极和蒙古​​等偏远地区与游牧部落一起猎鹰的旅行很流行。

降低风险

随着企业家和基金经理追求爱好，其中一些爱好比其他爱好更危险，一些投资者对风险表示担忧，称如果基金经理追求抗死的壮举，他们甚至可能会撤资。

八年前，亿万富翁投资者比尔·阿克曼（Bill Ackman）和他的大学朋友兼基金经理同事惠特尼·蒂尔森（Whitney Tilson）组织了二十多位基金经理和其他人参加由前海豹突击队领导的艰苦训练营。

据几位参加此次旅行的人士透露，这些人穿着潜水服在寒冷的太平洋中漂浮，乘船冲浪，并在加利福尼亚州的海滩上进行身体耐力测试。

这次经历的要求如此之高，以至于阿克曼的父亲对预定的旅行表示担忧，不是为了他的儿子，而是为了另一位报名参加的基金经理。所有的人都安全返回并讲述了这次经历。

蒂尔森和阿克曼拒绝置评。

一位熟悉那次旅行的人士表示，这种情况可能不会再发生，部分原因是这是一项潜在风险很大的事情。

Svea Herbst-Bayliss、Tatiana Bautzer 和 Julia Harte 的报道，Nupur Anand 的补充报道；编辑：Paritosh Bansal 和 Anna Driver ; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 10:19:17 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/jaunts-jets-not-risky-adventures-norm-wealthy-travelers-2023-06-27/ https://www.reuters.com/world/jaunts-jets-not-risky-adventures-norm-wealthy-travelers-2023-06-27/Svea Herbst-Bayliss, Tatiana Bautzer, Julia Harte泰坦尼克号潜水/财富 (PIX) Analysis: Bolivia's creaking big state model rings warning bell in South America

玻利维亚的“经济奇迹”是2000年代和2010年代的繁荣，多年来的国家支出使数百万人跻身中产阶级，但现在正在摇摇欲坠，这是对更广泛的地区与高通胀、政府金库萎缩和增长乏力作斗争的一个警告信号。

多年来，这个安第斯国家一直是南美洲经济增长率最快的国家之一，因为对自然资源（主要是天然气）的需求激增，帮助总统埃沃·莫拉莱斯的前左翼政府为社会项目提供资金并减少贫困。

但在过去十年中，天然气产量下降了约三分之一，导致外汇储备从 2014 年的 150 亿美元以上降至 2 月份的 35 亿美元，当时央行突然停止发布储备数据。

今年早些时候，硬通货的流失引发了恐慌，玻利维亚人在银行外排队提取美元。债券收益率大幅飙升，5 月份政府被迫出售 26 亿美元黄金储备的一半以筹集现金。

“实际上，玻利维亚已经耗尽了流动性，”前央行行长、经济学家何塞·加布里埃尔·埃斯皮诺萨表示。

玻利维亚政府预计 2022 年经济将实现相对强劲的增长，达到 3.5%，通货膨胀率保持在 3% 左右的低水平，部分原因是政府对燃料的补贴昂贵。

“玻利维亚经济稳定，正在增长，”经济部长马塞洛·黑山本月对记者表示。

但玻利维亚不断减少的储备和出口凸显了拉丁美洲的一个共同脆弱性，该地区大多数经济体高度依赖大宗商品，而这些大宗商品对全球价格、天气事件和政治情绪的波动非常敏感。

阿根廷的严重干旱严重影响了粮食产量和储备，危及与国际货币基金组织 (IMF) 达成的 440 亿美元债务协议。在全球没有。第二大铜生产国秘鲁，今年矿业投资预计将下降 19%，且在持续的政治动荡中产量已趋于稳定。

高盛拉丁美洲经济学家阿尔贝托·拉莫斯表示，巴西、智利和哥伦比亚政府也越来越多地采取高税收和公共部门支出政策。

“现在的模式正在转向一个非常大的国家，一种税收和支出的方式，”他说。 “鉴于公共部门的支出非常糟糕，这是有问题的。这会导致宏观经济表现不佳……最终可能会陷入危机。”

玻利维亚政府试图通过刺激大豆和牛肉生产来实现经济多元化，摆脱对天然气的过度依赖，而黄金抛售将有助于弥补公共预算缺口——但只是短暂的。

"It has calmed people a bit... but that amount (gained from the gold reserves sale), $1.3 billion, is not enough for Bolivia," said local financial analyst Jaime Dunn. "We are in a moment of tense calm, where we have to see what will happen in the coming weeks."

'BUYING TIME'

At the start of the year some banks experienced runs to withdraw deposits amid fear over sliding reserves, while black market demand for dollars spiked, putting pressure on the boliviano's currency peg, which has been just under 7 per dollar since 2008.

In April, the government was forced to put major lender Banco Fassil into administration, though authorities said it was an isolated case due to mismanagement.

Moody's rating agency cut its rating on Bolivia's sovereign debt in March, saying foreign exchange issues put "macroeconomic stability at risk for Bolivia in general."

Sovereign bond yields soared from under 10%, where they had been for years, to a peak of over 40%, before settling around 25%.

Espinoza, the former central bank director, said the recent turbulence was putting at risk the big-spending "economic miracle" of Morales' ruling socialist MAS party. The government would have to shift tactics, he argued.

"Otherwise it will be very difficult for us to reach a scenario where macroeconomic accounts stabilize," he said. "If you don't solve this we are going to keep on just buying time. And at some point the gold is going to run out."

Reporting by Raúl Cortés Fernández and Daniel Ramos; Editing by Adam Jourdan and Rosalba O'Brien ; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 10:15:20 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/bolivias-creaking-big-state-model-rings-warning-bell-south-america-2023-06-27/ https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/bolivias-creaking-big-state-model-rings-warning-bell-south-america-2023-06-27/Raul Cortes, Daniel Ramos BOLIVIA ECONOMY/ (ANALYSIS, GRAPHIC, PIX) For America's political elite, family links to slavery aboundSummary:
  • To read the full Part 1 of the Reuters series, Slavery's Descendants: America's Family Secret,

As US lawmakers commemorated the end of slavery by celebrating Juneteenth this month, many of them could have looked no further than their own family histories to find a more personal connection to what's often called America's “original sin.”

In researching the genealogies of America's political elite, a Reuters examination found that a fifth of the nation's congressmen, living presidents, Supreme Court justices and governors are direct descendants of ancestors who enslaved Black people.

Among 536 members of the last sitting Congress, for example, Reuters determined at least 100 descend from slaveholders. Of that group, more than a quarter of the Senate – 28 members – can trace their families to at least one slaveholder.

Among those lawmakers from the 117th Congress are Democrats and Republicans alike. They include some of the most influential politicians in America: Republican senators Mitch McConnell, Lindsey Graham and Tom Cotton, and Democrats Elizabeth Warren, Tammy Duckworth and Jeanne Shaheen.

In addition, Reuters determined that President Joe Biden and every living former US president – except Donald Trump – are direct descendants of slaveholders: Jimmy Carter, George W. Bush, Bill Clinton and – through his white mother's side – Barack Obama. Two of the nine sitting US Supreme Court justices – Amy Coney Barrett and Neil Gorsuch – also have direct ancestors who enslaved people.

In 2022, 11 of the 50 US states also had governors who are descendants of slaveholders, Reuters found. They include eight chief executives of the 11 states that formed the Confederate States of America, which seceded and waged war to preserve slavery. Two are seeking the Republican nomination for president: Asa Hutchinson, the former governor of Arkansas, and Doug Burgum of North Dakota.

Reuters found that at least 8% of Democrats in the last Congress and 28% of Republicans have such ancestors. The preponderance of Republicans reflects the party's strength in the South, where slavery was concentrated. Although white people enslaved Black people in Northern states in early America, by the eve of the Civil War, slavery was almost entirely a Southern enterprise.

South Carolina, where the Civil War began, illustrates the familial ties between lawmakers and the nation's history of slavery. Every member of the state's nine-person delegation to the last Congress has an ancestral link. The state's two Black members of Congress – Senator and Republican presidential candidate Tim Scott and Representative James Clyburn, a powerful Democrat – have forebears who were enslaved. Each of the seven white lawmakers who served in the 117th Congress is a direct descendant of a slaveholder, Reuters found. So too is the state's Republican governor, Henry McMaster.

The new insights into the political elite's ancestral links to slavery come at a time of renewed and intense debate about the meaning of the institution's legacy and what, if anything, lawmakers should do about it. Such topics include what to teach about slavery and racism in America's classrooms; the future of affirmative action in college admissions; and how to address the persistent inequality in income and wealth for Black households, including monetary reparations.

A Reuters/Ipsos poll for this report showed that white respondents who said they're aware of having a slaveholding ancestor were more likely than other white people to support paying reparations: 42% backed the idea, compared to 24% who said their ancestors did not enslave people.

The Reuters examination reveals how intimately tied America remains to the institution of slavery, including through the “people who make the laws that govern our country,” said Henry Louis Gates Jr, a professor at Harvard University who focuses on African and African American research and hosts the popular television genealogy show Finding Your Roots on PBS.

Gates said identifying those familial connections to slaveholders is “not another chapter in the blame game. We do not inherit guilt for our ancestors' actions.”

“It's just to say: Look at how closely linked we are to the institution of slavery, and how it informed the lives of the ancestors of people who represent us in the United States Congress today,” Gates said. “This is a learning opportunity for each individual. It is also a learning opportunity for their constituency … and for the American people as a whole.”

In addition to the political elite Reuters identified -- which include lawmakers representing northern states such as New Hampshire, Maine and Massachusetts -- “there are millions of Americans who are descendants of enslavers as well,” said Tony Burroughs, a genealogist who specializes in helping Black Americans trace their ancestries.

Census figures from 1860 indicate that 1 in 4 households in states where slavery was legal enslaved people, according to data from IPUMS' National Historical Geographic Information System. What's unclear is how the proportion of lawmakers who descend from slaveholders compares to that of all Americans. Among scholars, there is no agreement on precisely how many Americans today have a forebear who enslaved people.

To be sure, many white Americans whose ancestors came to America before the Civil War have family ties to the institution of slavery, and Northerners and Southerners alike reaped enormous economic benefits from enslaved labor.

Ancestral ties to slaveholders have been documented previously for a handful of leaders, including Biden ,Obama and McConnell . Scholars and journalists have also extensively examined slavery and its legacy, including how the North profited from the institution, and the role slavery played in decisions of past political leaders during the formation of America and after emancipation .

The Reuters examination is different. It focuses on the most powerful US officeholders of today, many of whom have staked key positions on policies related to race. It reveals for the first time, in breadth and in detail, the extent of those leaders' ancestral connections to what's commonly called America's “original sin.” And it explores what it may mean for them to learn – in personal, specific and sometimes graphic ways – the facts behind their own kin's part in slavery.

To trace the lineages of the political elite, Reuters assembled tens of thousands of pieces of information contained in thousands of pages of documents. Reporters only considered evidence of slaveholding that occurred after the founding of the United States. Journalists also limited their research to direct lineal descendants of the present-day elite rather than building sprawling family trees that included distant cousins.

In its reporting, Reuters analyzed US census records, including antebellum tallies of enslaved people known as “slave schedules,” as well as tax documents, estate records, family Bibles, newspaper accounts, and birth and death certificates. The records – in some cases, family wills that show enslaved human beings bequeathed along with feather beds and farm animals – provide a visceral link between today's decision makers and slavery.

The Reuters research was then vetted by board-certified genealogists, who reviewed each case linking a contemporary leader to a slaveholding ancestor. In instances in which journalists identified politicians with multiple slaveholding ancestors, Reuters focused on the lineage tracing to the ancestor who enslaved the most people.

In many cases, journalists identified politicians for whom there was strong evidence of an ancestral slaveholder, but insufficient underlying documentation to be certain. Those notables were not included in the Reuters analysis. And because other records that could demonstrate slaveholding have been lost or destroyed over time, “it's a great possibility that you have an undercount,” Burroughs said.

Among the examples of lawmakers and their ancestral ties to slavery:

SENATOR LINDSEY GRAHAM: The great-great-great-grandfather of Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican from South Carolina. After the death of Graham's direct ancestor, Joseph Maddox, a receipt from the sale of his property was prepared. Dated February 1, 1845, it shows the purchase of eight people Maddox had enslaved. Among them were five children: Sela, Rubin, James, Sal and Green. The “Negro man Sam” was sold for $155.25. Their names are listed alongside items including a sorrel horse ($10.50) and a folding table ($9.87).

“Senator Graham has called slavery 'the original sin of the country,'” an aide said in a short written statement in response to a detailed briefing on the Reuters findings about Maddox. Graham didn't respond to an interview request. In past public remarks, he has spoken about the need to focus on building “a more perfect union rather than looking backward.”

REPRESENTATIVE NANCY MACE: The great-great-great-grandmother of Representative Nancy Mace, a Republican from South Carolina. The ancestor, Drucilla Mace, had a son, John Mace, who was also a slaveholder. Decades after emancipation, a formerly enslaved man was interviewed and recalled being made to work for John Mace, who in 1860 enslaved seven people. John Mace is the great-great-grandfather of Nancy Mace.

In an interview in 1937 , the man, Hector Godbolt, recounted watching an overseer summoned by John Mace's wife put an enslaved person over a fence plank and whip him 75 times with a “cat o'nine tails,” named for the nine knotted strands that ensure each lash inflicted searing pain. After 75 lashes, Godbolt recalled, “Blood run down off him just like you see a stream run.”

Nancy Mace initially agreed to an interview, then canceled. She later provided this statement in response to the family tree Reuters provided: “I don't recognize these people named and can't confirm they are relatives, but slavery was a stain on this country and we as Americans should be grateful for the progress we've made since the 1860s.”

SENATOR TAMMY DUCKWORTH: The great-great-great-great-great-grandfather of Senator Tammy Duckworth, a Democrat from Illinois. Duckworth described the facts Reuters unearthed as “gut-wrenching.” In an 1829 appraisal of the estate of her ancestor, Henry Coe, the names of the enslaved – and their assessed dollar values – are bookended by farm animals: seven sheep and a lamb, and a bull calf.

Coe left to various family members “my negro woman Margaret until she shall arrive at the age of forty years, and my negro boy Isaac until he is thirty-six years old, also my negro boy Warner until he is thirty-six years old …” and “my negro boy George … till he is thirty-six years old.” The will said that each would be freed when reaching the stated age. Reuters could not determine what became of three of the enslaved. But a Freedom Suit in Virginia in 1858 shows that Isaac Franklin – the child named Isaac mentioned in the Coe will – sought emancipation at age 36. By the 1860 census, he was listed in Frederick County, Virginia, living as a free man and working as a blacksmith.

Duckworth is a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution, a service organization of women descended from veterans of the Revolutionary War. She said she hadn't known about her familial ties to slavery. “There's definitely political implications of the subject,” Duckworth said in an interview, when asked if she was reluctant to discuss it. “But I think it's a disservice to our nation and our history to walk away from this. If I am going to claim – and be proud that – I am a Daughter of the American Revolution, then I have to acknowledge that I am also a daughter of people who enslaved other people.”

None of the 118 leaders identified by Reuters disputed the findings that at least one of their ancestors had enslaved people. In a letter describing the project to them, Reuters made clear that it was not suggesting they were “personally responsible for the actions of ancestors who lived 160 or more years ago.” Even so, few leaders were willing to discuss their family ties to slavery.

Reporters contacted each of the 100 current or former members of Congress and the 18 presidents, governors or justices, providing the letter along with a family tree and documents showing their ancestral link to a slaveholding forebear. Of the 100 congressional lawmakers, 24 responded to the materials Reuters delivered. Another nine said they had no comment. The remaining 67 offered no reply.

To explore more about the connections to slavery of each of the 118 leaders, to see how they responded to the Reuters findings, and to explore documents that list the names of the enslaved people held by some of their ancestors, click here .

In researching America's political elite, Reuters found names – almost always just a first name – of 712 people enslaved by the ancestors of the political elite. Even with a first name, tracing those individuals forward to a census where they are recorded in full is often exceedingly difficult.

Genealogists say white people who excavate their ancestry could help Black Americans by finding information that enables them to trace their own ancestries. Black genealogy faces a special hurdle: Before 1870, census takers almost never recorded the names of the enslaved in the United States, instead listing ages and genders. But white families may have other documents – such as wills, plantation records or family Bibles that list the names of the enslaved – or know where to find them.

  • Petrol subsidy, forex restrictions removed
  • Disputed election deeply polarised Nigeria
  • Some Nigerians link Tinubu to Buhari legacy
  • Corruption, patronage networks entrenched

New Nigerian President Bola Tinubu has moved at lightning speed in his first month in office, implementing a raft of radical changes aimed at finally unleashing the full potential of Africa's sluggish economic giant.

But while his rapid headway on reforms has wowed investors , some analysts, observers and business leaders warn that bigger challenges await and question whether the 71-year-old - viewed by many as part of Nigeria's old guard - is really the man to take them on.

"There has been a big policy shift (but) I think there are things that investors would like to see happening to really be convinced that this is a clean break from the past," said Jason Tuvey, deputy chief emerging markets economist at Capital Economics.

Nigeria today faces record debt, unemployment is worryingly high, and power shortages have contributed to years of anaemic growth. Oil output is shrinking. And rampant insecurity has placed swathes of the countryside outside government control.

Solving those problems would be hard. But the task is made harder, observers say, by the rampant corruption and entrenched patronage networks so often blamed for the country's woes.

"The path to political power in Nigeria, over time, has always been through these vested interests," said Bismarck Rewane, CEO at Financial Derivatives Company in Lagos.

"When you deny them of their source of livelihood, then they will fight back."

KEEPING THE PEOPLE ON SIDE

Days after his inauguration, Tinubu scrapped a decades-old petrol subsidy. He then quickly suspended the central bank governor and freed up the exchange rate .

Both reforms should have long-term payoffs. Cementing them in the near-term won't be easy, however.

In a televised appeal, Tinubu argued ending the costly subsidy would free up money for education, regular power supply and healthcare, and "save our country from going under".

But the subsidy was popular.

Petrol prices have nearly tripled , hitting millions of households and small businesses that rely on petrol for power because the national grid is patchy. Transport fares have soared for workers and farmers taking produce to market.

"Tinubu said he was the best man for the job but we go suffer already," said Lagos driver Tunau Taiwo, 38. "What will happen after six months?"

An attempt to reduce the subsidy a decade ago provoked protests, forcing the government to backtrack. And unions are calling for Tinubu to reverse course or, failing that, impose a six-fold hike in the minimum wage .

Ending forex restrictions and unifying the exchange rate to end chronic dollar shortages will cause further pain.

The resulting naira devaluation could accelerate inflation in a country where four in 10 live below the poverty line.

Tinubu won't be able to count on post-election popularity while he waits for reforms to bear fruit, having garnered the fewest votes of any president since military rule ended in 1999.

His win is still being challenged in court .

"Nigeria was already hurting, so he needs to build consensus around the reforms. He has a legitimacy deficit," said Nnamdi Obasi, senior Nigeria advisor for the International Crisis Group think-tank.

ENTRENCHED NETWORKS

Tinubu's ambitions to build a $1 trillion economy in eight years could come unstuck in part due to chronic power shortages. The national grid produces only 4,500 megawatts, leaving millions in the dark.

Getting the lights on would be a major win, but to do so some say Tinubu must remove grid subsidies and cut red tape.

"If deregulation happens and actual prices are reflected, then the value proposition becomes crystal clear, and there will be more investors willing to invest in the sector," said Prince Ojeabulu, CEO at renewables firm Rensource Energy.

But Nigerian state authority is largely built on control and subsidies that keep prices low and vested interests happy.

Tackling insecurity will be equally thorny.

When predecessor Muhammadu Buhari came to power in 2015, many hoped the retired major general would successfully crack down on armed groups.

Instead, violence that had mostly been confined to the northeast has spread.

Tinubu cleaned house last week, removing security chiefs and the head of police. But he faces obstacles.

The military has its own entrenched patronage system, while political analysts say armed groups in the Nigeria Delta involved in industrial-scale oil theft operate with support from some politicians.

And some northwestern armed gangs behind kidnapping rings started as crime-fighting vigilante groups backed by state-governments.

Tinubu will be judged on how he tackles these networks, their corruption and criminality. Analysts say there are reasons to question his commitment.

Tinubu has said he will set up a surveillance unit to protect oil pipelines and create "anti-terrorist battalions" and special forces to fight jihadists and armed gangs. He also wants the military involved in community initiatives to "win hearts and minds."

As a member of Buhari's ruling party, Tinubu benefited from a political machine and largely owes his election victory to its deep political, religious and tribal networks.

Observers worry that could leave the new president beholden to them. Tinubu suspended the head of the financial and economic crimes agency, but has yet to outline an anti-graft plan.

"He has never been known to be a great fighter of corruption," said Obasi. "He hasn't said anything memorable about it and his body language doesn't suggest anything revolutionary will be done."

周一，周奥利维亚 (Olivia Chow) 成为首位当选加拿大最大城市多伦多市长的华裔加拿大人，她承诺支持租房者、倡导社会事业并削弱其办公室的广泛权力。

"I would dedicate myself to work tirelessly in building a city that is more caring, affordable, and safe, where everyone belongs," Chow told her supporters during the victory speech.

Chow secured 37.2% vote, according to preliminary results, ahead of her nearest rival Ana Bailao, former deputy mayor.

A prominent voice in progressive politics, Chow's campaign drew on her record as a former member of parliament in Ottawa and as a Toronto city councillor, and leaned on historic relationships established by her late husband, former New Democratic Party (NDP) and federal opposition leader Jack Layton.

Chow, 66, will be the first woman to serve as mayor since Barbara Hall in 1997. She previously ran for mayor in 2014, when she came in third.

Born in Hong Kong, Chow emigrated to Canada at the age of 13, and graduated from the University of Guelph with a degree in fine art.

Chow takes over as mayor after the resignation of John Tory , conservative-leaning mayor who won his third election last October. The married Tory left office in February after acknowledging he had had an affair with a staff member.

Chow will lead Canada's financial capital at a time of rising housing costs and an increase in violent attacks on public transit that have led to calls for more action by police. She has pledged to build 25,000 rent-controlled homes over eight years to tackle the soaring rents.

Since the start of the campaign, Chow had held a wide lead on her rivals in opinion polls. Tory had endorsed his former deputy Bailao, while Ontario Premier Doug Ford had endorsed former Toronto Chief of Police Mark Saunders.

Ford congratulated Chow, and said he was willing to work with anyone ready to "work with our government to better our city and province."
